etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Thomas Blount (1618–1679), antiquary and lexicographer. From classical Latin mustēlīnus of or belonging to a weasel from mustēla (also mustella) weasel, of uncertain origin (perhaps related to mūs) + -īnus

definitions: Of or like a weasel; (Zoology) of, belonging to, or characteristic of the weasel family Mustelidae or the subfamily Mustelinae.
A mustelid; (now usually) specifically a member of the subfamily Mustelinae, which includes weasels, martens, and polecats.
